subject: RE: [junit] Is Junit-based testing REALLY possible for commercial software development ?

messageBody:
Cedric,

My experience is that developer-written tests shorten the time it takes me
to get deployable code. They dramatically reduce the time necessary to go
from "yeah, I'm done" to really deployable. One problem is that this
debugging time is often not carefully accounted for so it seems I'm taking
longer. Once I factor in the productivity I gain from not having all those
interruptions, though, I can see that I'm going faster.

One reason may be that writing the tests is overlapped with a lot of
analysis and design thinking I would have to do anyway. I end up with
analysis, design, and tests in roughly the same time it would have taken me
to do the analysis and design without the tests. This only applies when I
write tests first. Test-first also neatly solves the "we don't have time to
write tests now that the code is 'done'" problem.

Sincerely yours,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

>
> A few thoughts.
>
>
> - Will thorough testing make the project take longer? Of course it
> will. Either in time or in programmers. After all, we
> are talking about
> writing more code, so the number of man.months is going to go up as
> well.
>
> The way to solve this problem is to include testing in the planning
> and project features and deadlines accordingly, but for
> having been there as
> well, I agree that it's not always possible.
